content.description: An outstanding route located in the round, amphitheater portion of The Main Wall. Thin ledges down low lead to a shallow dihedral and a large flake located below the anchors. Precise footwork on meager footholds will help alleviate some of the pump at several clip stances. The rock in this area tends to hold chalk even after a rain, so don't be surprised if you feel like the holds have already been "ticked".
content.protection: Bolts: well protected. Chains for rappel or lower.
content.location: The second line of bolts left of the obvious, bolted crack route - Community Service.

content.description: Neat route with fun moves and good rock. You can do a 5.8 crack start to the ledge if you don't want to climb the face.
content.location: Center of main wall.

content.description: I'm not sure if this has a name or who did the first ascent. Maybe someone will let us know when they see this. Climb the corner to the left of Valentine Arete route. The only anchor in the area is to climb up and right to use the anchor on Valentine Arete. Be careful if you do this!
content.protection: Nuts up to #3 Camalot (or TR off the Valentine Arete anchor)
content.location: Just left of Valentine Arete on the Main Wall

content.description: The beginning is a bit stout for a 5.8.  Good warm-up.
content.location: At the far left end of the Main Wall, this is the route on the left side of the obvious arete, starting in the dirt clearing.  Goes up the face left of the arete and right of the dihedral.

content.description: Steep face. PUMP up to a ledge, then to the top of the cliff.
content.location: Center of the main wall.  Right route on the large cliff that sits closest to the trail. Very orange rock

content.description: 5.9 layback crack then bolted face up top. Face is probably 10a if you go right for a rest and 10b if you go straight up.
content.protection: Nuts & Cams for bottom crack & start of top section, then bolts.
content.location: Crack + face directly to the right of "Community Service". Route #4 on the topo on the main page.

content.description: This dihedral climb protects well, with mostly no-hands clipping stances.  Fun stemming leads to hand jams and jugs.  Some loose/hollow-sounding rocks, but nothing too scary.  The final 10 feet are overhanging with beautiful jugs.
content.protection: Standard rack up to 3" will more than cover your needs.  There is a "fixed" cam halfway up.  Chains with new bolts at the top.
content.location: This crack is in the dihedral just left of the first three bolt lines encountered at the Main Wall.  Starts on a ledge, and leads up to an overhang with chains on the left side.

content.description: Climb bolt line using arete if needed over the first of 2 small roofs.  Use will find some relief by using the crack on your left as you approach the upper roof.  Anchors are just below large overhanging block.
content.location: This route is found around the corner from Valentine's Arete.  Start just left of a 15' pillar that separates the .12 roof and Foreplay.

content.description: This is the obvious corner right of Four Play. The climbing is enjoyable and never harder than moderate 5.9. This climb is worth doing if you have the correct rack.
content.protection: Mostly larger cams. I don't think a number 6 camalot is necessary, But you can use it, and there are some opportunities for smaller placements. It is easy to eyeball from the base and see what you need. This route used to have a single ring bolt anchor, requiring you to finish on four play,  but now has a two bolt anchor of its own.
content.location: The obvious, wide, left-facing corner just to the right of Four Play.

content.description: This climb is unnamed and rated 5.10 in the Tucson Select Sport Climbing book.  It has some hard moves and the clips are very tricky and sketchy on the lower part.  The crux move feels harder than straight 5.10.
content.location: Leftmost route on the Main Wall, left of I've Been Robbed.

content.description: Worth doing despite some choss and dirt, if you brought your rack.  The main roof and the bulge just following are fun, then the quality deteriorates.  You can finish at the anchors of either the 12a to the left, or the 10 to the right (recommended as it does add one more fun move at the top).
content.location: This is the corner crack with multiple roofs, just right of "Send It" (two routes right of Valentine Arete).

content.description: Very first route you encounter when hiking to the Main Wall (far right side of main wall if viewed from across the canyon).
content.protection: Bolts with hangers.  2 bolts with chain at top anchor.
content.location: Bolt line on the far right side of the Main Wall.  This is the first bolts seen on the approach.  Shares start with Massive Head Wound.

content.description: This route has a cool crux move and the bolt will keep you well off the ledge.  The second ledge doesn't come into play as the lack of holds forces you on to the overhanging face.  Great stances before each of the 3 hard sections mean you don't have to be an enduro king.  I say stances but really it is the ground where you start and the two ledges you can completely recover on.
content.location: Starts just left of the fat crack that is left of the Fish.  It is about 10 feet right and just around the corner from Welcome to Milagrosa

content.description: Climb obvious bolt line using sidepulls and good edges up steep wall and over roof.  Roof is protected by two bolts.
content.location: First route to the left of Valentine's Day Arete

content.description: Another good warm up for your day at Milagrosa.
content.location: Starts in a shallow corner then up the arete 10 feet  left of Lugee Head.

content.description: Send it goes up the face to the obvious roof to the right of Valentine Arete.

Climbs a blunt arete on good edges with a fun balance move getting to the 3rd bolt. The "guide" calls it 11a, but I climbed it before I knew the rating and thought it felt like 10c/d...since I don't typically flash 11a on Mt Lemmon.
content.location: 2nd bolted route from the entrance end, goes up a blunt arete.

content.description: Fun climbing on good edges. Rest on the ledge if you're pumped, 'cause the crux is at the top.
content.location: Face just right of the crack route right of Community Service.

content.description: Short but fun face climbing in between For the People and Commonwealth. One of the easier routes in the area and a good recent addition for beginners.
content.location: One of the first routes at main wall, just left of a chimney-like crack system and right of a large group of boulders.

content.description: Steep face moves get you to a huge ledge and then 12 more feet get you to the chains.
content.location: Center of the main wall.  Left side of the big wall that comes closest to the trail. This route and Where the Buffalo Roam are the only climbs on this section of face.

content.description:
I thought this route was called Stealin' but it is actually I've Been Robbed.  See comments. 

  It is a short climb that packs a lot in.  I like starting in the crack and ignoring all of the big holds to the left.  It makes the climb more challenging and forces you to make some stylish moves.  The crux near the top of the route involves pulling on pretty small holds.
content.location: second bolted route to the left of Valentine's Day Arete, second to last route on main wall

climbs.name: Four Play
climbs.fa: Mike Arqueso, Ron Farrell, Tony Lusk, Mike Witt (1990)

content.description: Relative low angle (not slabby) and very thin holds on a long and fairly sustained route.  Great protection and quality rock make this a route to do.
content.location: long face to the right of Send Me, the obvious bolted .12a roof

content.description: A thin crux down low and a wide crux up high. Some good hand jams are up there for those willing to find them!
content.protection: Single rack with two hand-sized pieces or so
content.location: The obvious crack system just right of Let Freedom Ping.

content.description: This pitch was established in hopes to increase the amount of moderate climbs available for the people who just might not be at the 5.11 heaven level. The top is steep and fun.  Keep your eyes out for the jugs. Be aware that the route climbs through a chossy black band of rock.  This detracts from the overall quality of the pitch.
content.protection: The first bolt is a little high and if this grade is within your limits you will be fine getting to that first bolt, otherwise use a stick clip or plug a #1-2 sized Camalot in the crack at the start.
content.location: The first route you encounter at the main wall.

content.description:
The Fish starts with two bolts of moderate climbing to a large ledge.  After another two bolts the climber can optionally transition off-route for a full rest.  The route comes into its own after this section.  Ascend a series of smooth crimps using delicate feet to obtain a deep in-cut.  Power through to a featured horizontal weakness that allows some recovery.  Climb the dark rock using two finger crimps, a small pocket, and shallow edges.  The path of least resistance may require some trial and error. 

The Fish has the reputation of being a bad route; however, I personally found it quite enjoyable.  While certainly not a classic like The Wizard, The Fish has interesting movement on nice rock.  The two ledges detract from the route but the top sequence is sustained enough for me.
content.location: Found in the first amphitheater, The Fish is located immediately to the left of The Wizard.  The route starts where the wall juts out and the trail slightly descends.

content.description: 5.hard.  Crux comes early in this one.
content.protection: Lots o' bolts + anchors at top.
content.location: Just left of Community Service. Trends right at first, then goes straight up (more or less).

content.description:
Another stop in the "not necessarily worth bringing your rack for but worth doing if you brought your rack" tour, aka the Milagrosa trad circuit. 

 In John Hinrichson's on-line guide he says that a "thin crack (5.8) with good gear leads to a ledge; walk left to larger crack (5.10) that takes good but slightly tricky pro. A variation is to follow the finger crack (5.10) to the anchors of Welcome to Milagrosa." After reaching the ledge the finger crack appeared to be the better choice as the big crack/chimney looks pretty chossy. Indeed, while climbing the finger crack I found myself stemming over to the big crack on a few occasions and on one of those occasions the rock on the side of the big crack broke, sending me for a ride on a green C3 which thankfully held. Next time I'll forgo the stem rests, tempting as they are, and just climb up the finger crack which is pretty fun with a bulging crux move near the top. The finger crack is a little chossy but good gear and solid locks can be found.

 As is typical of Milagrosa gear routes, this won't be mistaken for a classic but is worth doing if you brought your rack.
content.protection: Light standard rack to a #2 camalot for the finger crack variation (which, as I say, appears to be the better option off the ledge). I can't comment on the larger crack except to say that it may be chossy. A red C3 protects the finger crack crux but there are other options as well. If doing the finger crack variation you can clip the chains on Welcome to Milagrosa. If doing the left-hand, larger crack, John's guide suggests that there are chains at the top, but I didn't notice any from below.
content.location: Starts a few feet left of Welcome to Milagrosa in an obvious, and by Milagrosa standards, attractive-looking crack.

content.description: Clean rock, moderately pumpy, great warm-up.  It was my friend's first .10a lead so it also good for new 10 leaders.
content.protection:
quickdraws

 Quick lowers installed by CASA in 2019.
content.location: It is the fourth bolted route on the main wall as you enter the canyon.  It is just to left of a large crack and to the right of a corner with some difficult sport climbs.

content.description: Probably the easiest sport route at the main wall.  This is a good warm up for Valentine's Arete.
content.location: One of the first routes encountered at the Main Wall.

content.description: Sustained face climbing up dark rock.    Shares anchors with Short Vacation.
content.location: Steep Face just right of Short Vacation. 4th route you come to on the Main Wall

content.description: A popular wall with the greatest concentration of climbs in thge canyon. Beautiful smooth orange faces with lots of crimps, as well as two of the canyon's most popular routes, Community Service (.10a) and Valentine Arete (.8) The northerly orientation make this a good place to chase shade, but that means it can be cold on chilly winter days. Gets some late-afternoon sun, which really makes the rock glow.
